sect1.title: Migration from &hpecloud; 5.x to &hpecloud; 5.SCP
sect1.para: The migration procedure is based on the following assumptions:

listitem.para: The customer is responsible for backing up all the control plane and deployer nodes to an external data store before starting the migration.

important.title: No Migration Rollback
important.para: We do not support rollback of migration after the process has been started.

listitem.para: Metering, monitoring, and logging (MML) data will not be migrated (a clean installation will be done using a new MML back-end included with &hpecloud; 5.SCP).
Any data that is not on a disk separate from the primary root partition will be lost during re-imaging. This includes &swift; objects and audit logs.
All &compnode;s are running supported Linux distributions:
&sls; 12 SP3 for &slsa; &compnode;s
&rhla; 7.3 for &rhla; &compnode;s
There are only supported input model services.
Ceph and VSA are not embedded in &productname; &productnumber;.
Only supported third-party integrations and extensions are installed.
There are no unsupported customized virtual environments.
No significant issues or alarms being reported by Monasca and OpsConsole

step.para: Obtain the &hpecloud; 5.SCP installation ISO and use the mount command to make its contents available on the deployer:
step.screen: (old-deployer)$ mkdir hos-5.scp (old-deployer)$ sudo mount HOS5SCP_ISO_FILE hos-5.scp (old-deployer)$ tar -xzvf hos-5.scp/hos/hlm-migration-tools.tar.gz ./

step.para: Run the validation playbook to ensure that the current cloud load and configuration is compatible with the migration process:
step.screen: (old-deployer)> git clone -b hp/prerelease/newton https://gerrit.suse.provo.cloud/hp/hlm-migration-tools (old-deployer)> cd hlm-migration-tools/ansible (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/hosts/verb_hosts pre-migration-validations.yml
step.para: The validation playbook checks the following:

listitem.para: That the &hpecloud; version number is either 5.0.1 or 5.0.2
&productname; &productnumber;-compatible Linux distributions on &compnode;s
System clock synchronization across cloud nodes
HA capacity of &contrnode;s (L3/DHCP agent)
HA capacity of &contrnode;s (&swift;)
Data model and &o_blockstore; back-end compatibility (no VSA, Ceph, or cmc-service)

step.para: Identify a candidate seed &contrnode; in the primary control plane. This node must meet the following requirements:

listitem.para: Networking connectivity is equivalent to that of the existing deployer.
It is a member of the database cluster (running the MySQL service).
It is not actively hosting any singleton &ostack; services (cinder-volume or nova-consoleauth). Test for empty output with the following command:

step.para: Prepare the cloud for migration:

listitem.para: Ensure that the data model enables deployer behavior by the new seed node. taroth 2018_02-27: what is this supposed to mean?
In the disks_*.yml file used by your server role that includes monitoring services, replace the existing Vertica partition definition with two Cassandra partitions:
listitem.screen: - name: cassandra_db size: (whatever size was used originally by vertica partition, less 1%) mount: /var/cassandra/data fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file consumer: name: vertica - name: cassandra_log size: 1% mount: /var/cassandra/commitlog fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file

listitem.para: Edit ~/openstack/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml and identify the cluster definition that already includes an entry for mysql in its service-components.

Ensure that lifecycle-manager is included in the same cluster's service-components list. If it was necessary to add this as a new entry, it will also need to be removed from its original position in the deployer.
Add a new entry for nova-placement-api alongside whichever cluster already includes nova-api.
Commit your changes to the Git model:
Consider the effect of control plane downtime on existing DHCP leases:
Default DHCP lease time is 48 hours as defined in the ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/neutron-common/templates/neutron.conf.j2 file by the dhcp_lease_duration parameter.
DHCP leases are administered by &o_netw; and dnsmasq. This functionality will not be available during the control plane downtime.
DHCP clients typically renew their leases either after 50% of the lease time or upon reboot.
Normally, this leaves a 24-hour window for control plane downtime at any point before workload's DHCP leases run out and cannot be renewed. This is enough for performing a migration.
To view the upcoming timeouts of DHCP leases, run the following command from a &contrnode;:
listitem.screen: for i in $(cat /var/run/neutron/dhcp/*/leases | awk '{print $1}'); do date -d @$i; done

listitem.para: If it is necessary to increase the DHCP lease time before migrating, open the ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/neutron-common/templates/neutron.conf.j2 and edit the dhcp_lease_duration parameter. Commit the change, and run the neutron-configure.yml playbook.

step.para: Decommission the seed node from the existing cloud (if the intended seed node hosts control plane services beyond the database): taroth 2018-02-27: is 'if the intended seed node hosts control plane services beyond the database' the condition which must be fulfilled to execute the following two actions (in the itemizedlist)? if yes, rephrase the sentence to: 'If the intended seed node hosts control plane services beyond the database, decommission the seed node from the existing cloud.' If the following two actions explain how to decommission, end the introductory sentence with a colon: 'If the intended seed node hosts control plane services beyond the database, decommission the seed node from the existing cloud:'

listitem.para: For non-DVR clouds, evacuate any existing &o_netw; L3 routers on the seed node:
SEED_HOST could be for example helion-cp1-c1-m2.
For correct behavior, you must use the --limit argument to select the target seed host. This will output a success or error message at the end of its run.

step.para: Re-image the seed controller as a &slsa;-based system:

listitem.para: Display the current network connections of the seed controller (before re-imaging) for reference and save it locally.
Reinstall the operating system on the seed node's primary disk using an ISO, cobbler (from the existing &hpecloud; 5.0.1+ deployer), or other provisioner.
If using cobbler, update the servers.yml entry for all nodes in the control plane to specify distro-id: sles12sp3-x86_64 in each one, and commit the change to Git:
listitem.screen: (old-deployer)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (old-deployer)> sudo cobbler system remove --name SEED_NODE_ID (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=SEED_NODE_ID
listitem.para: Replace SEED_NODE_ID with the ID of the seed node from the servers.yml file.
Otherwise reformat the disk using partitioning to match the current configuration.
Copy the entire ~stack directory from the original deployer:
Ensure that ~/sles12sp3sdk.iso was either transferred from the original deployer or is downloaded to the correct location under the sles12sp3sdk.iso name.
If cobbler will be used from the new seed for provisioning the remaining cloud &contrnode;s:
Ensure that the new deployer is able to reach ILO interfaces referenced in the servers.yml file:
If network accessibility to the ILOs requires special network configuration and you would like to use HLM for that process based on your model:
listitem.screen: (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-refresh-facts.yml (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts -l LOCAL_NODE_ID osconfig-run.yml
listitem.para: Replace LOCAL_NODE_ID with the ID of the local node from the verb_hosts file.
Kill the DHCP services running on the old deployer:

step.para: Mount the ~/sles12sp3.iso image to make it available to the &hpecloud; installer.

listitem.para: Ensure that ~/sles12sp3.iso was either transferred from the original deployer or is downloaded to the correct location under the sles12sp3.iso:
listitem.screen: (seed)> sudo mkdir -p /media/cdrom (seed)> sudo mount ~/sles12sp3.iso /media/cdrom (seed)> sudo vi /etc/zypp/repos.d/SLES12-SP3-12.3-0.repo

listitem.para: Update the baseurl line to read baseurl=file:///media/cdrom.

step.para: Install &hpecloud; 5.SCP on the new deployer by downloading and unpacking &hpecloud; 5.SCP installation content:
Prepare for running playbooks:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

step.para: Initialize ansible host facts and ensure that the existing cloud is fully addressable by the new deployer:
Prune the primary database to remove data that is no longer relevant:

warning.title: Downtime
warning.para: The cloud will not be available until all of the following steps are completed.

step.para: Stop or pause &ostack; services on the control plane (excluding the seeds that have been freshly imaged):
The SEED_HOST name must exactly match the host name that is referenced in hosts/verb_hosts, such as helion-cp1-c1-m1.
Create a database backup by retrieving MySQL database contents from another node (not the seed) in the database cluster:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-vertica-removal-cleanup.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-export.yml -e dbcontent=~/mysql_dump.sql

step.para: Re-image the remaining servers in the control plane.

listitem.para: Reinstall the operating systems on the control plane primary disks using an ISO, cobbler, or other provisioner. If using cobbler:
listitem.screen: (seed)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost prepare-sles-grub2.yml -e nodelist=NODE_IDs (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=NODE_IDs
listitem.para: Replace NODE_IDs by a comma-separated list of IDs of all non-seed control plane and deployer nodes in the servers.yml file.
Otherwise reformat the disk using partitioning to match the current configuration.

step.para: Perform the &hpecloud; 5.SCP installation using flags to enable database import:
Optionally, if the 3Par back-end was configured previously, follow the procedures to enable it again.

note.title: No Downtime
note.para: These steps do not cause service downtime and can be performed while the cloud is up and running.

step.para: Delete the database backup from the seed node:
If desired, transfer the deployer role in the &hpecloud; 5.SCP cloud to a different node, such as one that originally served as a dedicated deployer.

listitem.para: If the deployer will be moving to an entirely different cluster (for example, Database cluster to Controller cluster or standalone Deployer cluster), additional software packages need to be installed.
Edit ~/openstack/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml and move the lifecycle-manager from its current location into the new desired cluster service-components list. Commit the change to Git:
listitem.screen: (seed)> git commit -a -m "Enable lifecycle-manager for targeted seed node"

listitem.para: Kill the DHCP services running on the current seed:
Install the lifecycle-manager services on the new deployer:
NEW_DEPLOYER_HOST could be for example helion-cp1-c0-m1
Copy the home directory from the seed to the new deployer:
Unpack or copy &hpecloud; 5.SCP contents to the home directory of the new deployer.
Initialize the deployer node:

sect1.title: Migration from &hpecloud; 5.SCP to Ardana.Newton
sect1.para: The following procedure describes the process of migrating from &hpecloud; 5.SCP to Ardana.Newton.

step.para: Convert the helion Git repository to an openstack Git repository for use by Ardana:
step.screen: cd ~ cp -r helion openstack cd openstack git checkout site
step.para: Save a record of all manual changes that have been previously committed to the hos/ansible directory, as you will need to reapply them later:
Undo all manual changes:
Reset the codebase to make it ready for Ardana, then refactor the rest of the repository:
step.screen: git commit -a -m "Resetting codebase in prep for Ardana" git branch -m hos ardana git checkout ardana sed -i 's/hos/ardana/' .gitignore git commit -a -m "Prep for Ardana" git mv hos ardana git mv hos_extensions ardana_extensions for i in $(find -L my_cloud/config -xtype l); \ do ln -sfn $(readlink $i | sed 's/\/hos\//\/ardana\//') $i; done git commit -a -m "Conversion to Ardana" git checkout cp-persistent sed -i 's/component: helion-ca/component: ardana-ca/' \ my_cloud/persistent_state/private_data_control-plane-1.yml sed -i 's/helion_internal_ca/ardana_internal_ca/' \ my_cloud/persistent_state/private_data_control-plane-1.yml git commit -a -m "Conversion to Ardana" git checkout site git merge ardana -m "Conversion to Ardana" # reinstate the changes that were originally made to the contents of hos/ansible sed 's/ \([ab]\?[\/]\?\)hos\/ansible/ \1ardana\/ansible/g' /tmp/hos.diff | git apply git commit -a -m "Reinstated hos playbook customizations (batch)"

step.para: Remove and archive the &hpecloud; 5.SCP-related content:
Prepare the ardana_packager working directory to include existing &suse; repositories:
Install Ardana.Newton content onto deployer by unpacking the ardana installer into ~/ardana-0.35.0 and then running the following commands:
Install Ardana.Newton:
Reapply any changes to playbooks that were undone in the hos code tree in :
step.screen: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-iptables-rename.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ardana-upgrade.yml

sect1.title: Migration from Ardana.Newton to Ardana.Pike
sect1.para: The following instructions are suitable for use with RC2 build #0053.

step.para: Create the ardana user throughout the cloud nodes:
Mount the &productname; &productnumber; installation media on the host (after copying the ISO file into the user's home directory)
Add the contents of the ISO as a Zypper repository and begin installation:
step.screen: sudo zypper ar -G -f file:///opt/ardana_packager/SUSE-12-3/x86_64/repos/Cloud Cloud sudo zypper refresh

step.para: Begin the Ardana.Pike installation:
step.screen: sudo zypper -n in patterns-cloud-ardana sudo su - ardana ARDANA_INIT_AUTO=1 /usr/bin/ardana-init

step.para: Adjust data model to install cassandra instead of vertica (continuing as ardana user):
Replace vertica with cassandra in the service-components list:
In files where a cassandra_db partition exists, update its consumer name from vertica to cassandra and add an identical consumer block to the cassandra_log partition definition:
Update the data model:
step.screen: git commit -a -m 'Update data model for cassandra'

step.para: Prepare the repository for Pike installation:
step.screen: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

step.para: Prepare the servers for Pike infrastructure:

Set up &scc; repositories or link to existing ⪪ repositories. Replace the &hpecloud; &rhla; repositories on &rhel; &compnode;s with &productname; &productnumber; sources. Follow the public documentation for populating &suse; repositories and then proceed with the following command:
Run the Pike upgrade playbook:
If you had to run ardana-upgrade-from-legacy.yml multiple times in order to complete the upgrade, restart all services using ardana-stop.yml and ardana-start.yml.
